zones.name: Active Recovery
zones.description: Easy spinning. Conversation flows effortlessly. Use for recovery rides and warm-ups.

zones.name: Endurance
zones.description: All-day pace. Can speak in full sentences. This is where aerobic base is built.

zones.name: Tempo
zones.description: Comfortably hard. Conversation limited to short phrases. Sustainable for 1-3 hours.

zones.name: G Spot
zones.description: The money zone for gravel. Hard but sustainable. Where races are won.

zones.name: Threshold
zones.description: Race pace for shorter events. Sustainable for 20-60 minutes max.

zones.name: VO2max
zones.description: Hard breathing. 3-8 minute intervals. Builds top-end power.

zones.name: Anaerobic
zones.description: All-out efforts. 30 seconds to 2 minutes. Sprints and attacks.

glossary.definition: Functional Threshold Power. The highest power you can sustain for approximately one hour. All training zones are based on this number.
Training Stress Score. A measure of workout load based on duration and intensity. 1 hour at FTP = 100 TSS.
Chronic Training Load. 42-day rolling average of daily TSS. Proxy for 'fitness.' Good amateurs: 60-80. Pros: 140+.
Acute Training Load. 7-day rolling average of daily TSS. Proxy for 'fatigue.'
Training Stress Balance. Yesterday's CTL minus yesterday's ATL. Proxy for 'form' or freshness. Negative = fatigued, positive = fresh. Race best at +5 to +20.
Normalized Power. Estimate of the constant power that would produce the same physiological cost as your variable power output.
Intensity Factor. Ratio of Normalized Power to FTP (IF = NP ÷ FTP). IF of 1.0 means you averaged FTP.
Watts per kilogram. Power relative to body weight. Good amateurs ~4 W/kg, elite pros 6+ W/kg.
Variability Index. NP divided by Average Power. Shows how variable your power was. 1.0 = perfectly steady.
Efficiency Factor. NP divided by Average HR. Higher = better aerobic efficiency. Track over time.
Aerobic Decoupling. Compares first-half to second-half power-to-HR ratio. <5% = good aerobic fitness.
Performance Management Chart. Graph showing CTL, ATL, and TSB over time. The main planning tool in TrainingPeaks.
Rate of Perceived Exertion. Subjective 1-10 scale of how hard an effort feels. Essential when power isn't available.
Zone 2, Endurance zone. 55-75% FTP. The foundation of aerobic training.
Fat oxidation maximum. The intensity where your body burns the most fat per minute. Usually upper Z2.
Maximum oxygen uptake. Your aerobic ceiling. Improved with high-intensity intervals.
Your ability to produce power above threshold. Like a matches—burn them wisely.
Heart Rate Variability. Variation in time between heartbeats. Higher generally = better recovered.
Systematic variation of training load over time. Prevents plateaus and manages fatigue.
80% easy (Z1-Z2) / 20% hard (Z4+). Minimal time in the middle. Research-backed approach.
Concentrated training blocks focusing on one quality at a time.
Most volume at low intensity, progressively less at higher intensities. Classic endurance approach.
Planned reduction in training load before a race. Maintains intensity, drops volume.
Short, sharp efforts 1-2 days before race. Activates systems without creating fatigue.

skills.name: Loose Surface Cornering
skills.description: Lean the bike, not your body. Weight the outside pedal. Look through the turn, not at the ground. Enter wide, apex late, exit wide. Scrub speed before the turn, not during.

skills.name: Cadence Control
skills.description: Slow twitch fibers (<80 rpm) for maintaining speed on flats. Fast twitch fibers (>95 rpm) for changing speed and steep hills. Practice varying cadence to develop feel for what works when.

skills.name: Braking Technique
skills.description: Feather brakes gradually—never grab. Front brake does most of the stopping. Rear brake for fine adjustments. Brake before turns, not during. Practice controlled rear-wheel skidding on low-risk gravel to learn limits.

skills.name: Steep Climbs (15-25%)
skills.description: Keep momentum going in—you won't get it back. Stay seated for rear wheel traction. Weight over rear wheel, hands light on bars. Standing shifts weight forward and loses traction. Lower gear than you think you need.

skills.name: Track Standing
skills.description: Develops balance and handling ability. Start on slight uphill, front wheel turned slightly uphill. Gentle pedal pressure forward, handlebar corrections for balance. Practice until you can hold 30+ seconds.

skills.name: Bunny Hopping
skills.description: For obstacles you can't avoid. Compress down → pull up on bars → scoop back with feet → level out in air. Start with small obstacles. Even a 2-inch hop saves your wheels from impacts.

skills.name: Eating While Riding
skills.description: Practice unwrapping bars, opening bottles, and eating at pace. Find what foods you can eat at threshold. Never try new nutrition on race day.

skills.name: Group Riding & Pace Lines
skills.description: Hold your line. No sudden movements. Point out hazards. Pull through smoothly, peel off into the wind. Take shorter pulls into headwinds. Communication is everything.

skills.name: Mechanical Self-Sufficiency
skills.description: Practice fixing flats until it's automatic (target: under 5 minutes). Know how to adjust brakes and derailleurs. Carry the right tools. The race ends when you can't fix it.

three_acts.name: THE MADNESS
three_acts.whats_happening: Fresh legs, nervous energy, crowded course. Attacks fly. Adrenaline-fueled decisions.
three_acts.your_job: Go hard enough to find your group. Don't panic. Start eating immediately.

three_acts.name: FALSE DAWN
three_acts.whats_happening: Order returns. Groups stabilize. Pace becomes predictable. Feels manageable.
three_acts.your_job: Stay fueled and hydrated. Contribute to your group without overworking. Bank energy.

three_acts.name: THE PIPER
three_acts.whats_happening: The bill comes due. Under-fueled riders bonk. Under-prepared riders cramp. Mentally weak riders check out.
three_acts.your_job: Execute your plan while others fall apart. This is where the race happens.

race_tactics.key_quote: How could I keep going at this speed for less effort?

efficiency_tips.name: Draft Smart
efficiency_tips.content: Even on gravel, drafting helps. Don't be a hero. Take pulls, but don't try to show anyone how strong you are. Every minute at the front is energy you're not saving. Every minute in the draft is energy you're banking for later.

efficiency_tips.name: Read the Course
efficiency_tips.content: Always pick the best possible line. If the right line is packed down and smooth, why are you riding in potholes? Look ahead. Pick lines. Save watts.

efficiency_tips.name: Read the Wind
efficiency_tips.content: Headwind? Worth putting out more energy to put time on people. Tailwind? Your speed will be higher but you won't gain as much time for proportional power output. Don't hammer with a tailwind—save that for when it turns into a slog.

nutrition.pre_race_meal: 1-2g carbs/kg body weight, 3-4 hours before start
nutrition.key_principle: Practice everything in training. Nothing new on race day.

tires.key_insight: Wider is faster on gravel. Dylan Johnson testing showed MTB tires lose 8W on cobbles vs 42W for 35mm gravel tires.

recommendations.use_case: Fast smooth gravel, lots of pavement
recommendations.note: Fastest on smooth, slowest on rough
Fastest on rough, most comfortable, fewest flats

tires.unbound_recommendation: Go as wide as frame allows. 45mm minimum, 50mm+ preferred.
tires.bottom_line: Pick a durable, 'fast enough' tire in the widest width your frame allows. The actual best tire is the one that gets you to the finish line without flatting.

race_week.focus: Last moderate ride. Final bike check.
Travel day if needed. Stay hydrated.
Shake out travel. Course recon if possible.
Openers. Packet pickup. Final bike check.
Prep drop bags. Lay out kit. Visualize. Early to bed.

footer.body: You have the plan. You understand how training works, how to execute the workouts, how to fuel and hydrate, how to manage your mental game, and how to approach race day.
footer.middle: Not perfectly. Not heroically. Consistently. Intelligently. Over 12 weeks.
footer.confidence: On race morning, you'll stand at the start line knowing you did everything you could to prepare. That confidence—not hope, not optimism, but confidence based on completed work—is what this plan builds.
footer.emphasis_2: The race will be hard. You trained for hard.
